Every year we look at about 800 proposals for for allocations.
These are the larger sort of requests, and there's about another 800 or so that come in as startups.
We feel about 60,000 tickets since the beginning, so there's a lot of user support that goes on and then one of the more interesting things that we do is these.
We do these advanced support projects through organization.

We called the CSS extended Collaborative support Service in which exceed staff members engage with the research teams for up to a year and spend up to usually a quarter to maybe sometimes half amount of their time on these projects.

So they sent their, they become part of those groups for some period of time to help them in various ways, and often these are helping them get through difficult challenges in either code optimization, parallelization, scaling, implementation of new methods and algorithms, and these sorts of things.
Very often the research teams state that they would not be able to get these things done without this sort of support, so you're learning a lot of the things that are learned through this process.
But we do have staff who have made it a career to to to do this sort of work.

One of the interesting things is that we ask them at the end of these projects you know how much time did this save you, and many of them say, well, we wouldn't have done it, but many will have a pretty good sense of how much time they would have taken him otherwise.

And I really want to make a point here and that while this summer school is really about HPC and the history that exceed comes from is very HPC oriented, it actually provides a lot of services much beyond just the high performance computing we could provide high throughput computing cloud resources, data analytics resources, so there's a lot more to it than just HPC.
Every year we look at about 800 proposals for for allocations.
These are the larger sort of requests, and there's about another 800 or so that come in as startups.
We feel about 60,000 tickets since the beginning, so there's a lot of user support that goes on and then one of the more interesting things that we do is these.
We do these advanced support projects through organization.

We called the CSS extended Collaborative support Service in which exceed staff members engage with the research teams for up to a year and spend up to usually a quarter to maybe sometimes half amount of their time on these projects.

So they sent their, they become part of those groups for some period of time to help them in various ways, and often these are helping them get through difficult challenges in either code optimization, parallelization, scaling, implementation of new methods and algorithms, and these sorts of things.
Very often the research teams state that they would not be able to get these things done without this sort of support, so you're learning a lot of the things that are learned through this process.
But we do have staff who have made it a career to to to do this sort of work.

One of the interesting things is that we ask them at the end of these projects you know how much time did this save you, and many of them say, well, we wouldn't have done it, but many will have a pretty good sense of how much time they would have taken him otherwise.
So typically on average it's about 18 or so months that they save we we put in affectively about three months of effort.
So it's a pretty good return on investment for us.
